title: Some of the grown up parents that bought along my friends.
description: Some of the grown up parents that bought along my friends.

Todd Wise, a member of the Penn State Performing Magicians, introduced his parents, Larry and Diana Wise to Penn State President Graham B. Spanier. The open house coincided with Parents and Families weekend.
Graduate Richard Bosher, hugs his girlfriend, Kristie, at commencement ceremonies at Penn State Wilkes-Barre as his parents look on. Bosher earned his bachelor's degree in business.

WPSU publicist Jill Filby reads a story about Clifford the Big Red Dog to children and parents visiting the Penn State Public Broadcasting booth at the PA Green Energy Expo.

title: Debbie's parent's dog
description: This was one completely stupid animal. It later found and then actually ate a wasps nest, nearly killing itself in the process. Typical moronic dog.

title: Fairhaven 1993: before the growing pains
description:
August 1993 in the Fairhaven district of Bellingham, WA. I had just left Aberdeen and moved here at the end of June '93. This was during my parents' first visit to Bellingham. You're looking at me exactly 15 years ago.

Fairhaven has changed a lot. Eclipse Books has a fancy new (few years old) building of their own, and I can't even recall what's in this old building now. Village Books has also moved into a new addition, leaving their old space to other businesses. The green behind Village Books has developed into a park with benches, shelters, and an outdoor projection screen for summer movies.

That's not so bad.

A few blocks away, several brand new buildings have spring up. They tried to make them look "appropriate" for Fairhaven's quirky, artistic nature and for the "Victorian Old West" look of the old buildings. But the new buildings still are so shiny, so modern, so... commercial. I have mixed feelings about Fairhaven's growth.

title: The best Halloween party ever ... not
description: After attending a Halloween party in 1992, I decided to throw one the following year. After all, our hosts had made it look so easy! Determined to create the best Halloween party ever, I borrowed about a gazillion idea books from the local library for Halloweenie fun, food and games. I worked my butt off to create a Haunted Trail back in the woods. At my request, Tim sawed pieces of leftover plywood to create tombstones, which I spray-painted gray and stenciled with silly epitaphs, then added all sorts of goofy props – a rubber chicken nailed to a post is the only one I can remember now ... and I only remember it because I pounded my thumb with a sledgehammer white beating it into the ground. But all my work was for naught – come party night, it was so bitterly cold that I had to force all the kids out there, and they hated it. One party game called the Mummy Roll required groups wrapping up one team member in toilet paper. A bunch of tissue even got wrapped around the fan in the den (yep, the one that's two stories high). I thought I'd never get it all out. Several parents attended with their kids. I congratulated one of the moms on her witch outfit, and one of the dads on his biker costume ... then learned that neither of them were dressed up. (She was goth, he was really a biker.) It was several years before I was able to laugh about that embarrassing moment. My biggest mistake: Far too many guests were invited, ranging in age from 4 to 15. Several uninvited guests showed up as well. The whole event stressed me way out, and I ended up yelling at everyone. What a disaster! But there's good news: By the time this photo was taken, the party was over, the guests had fled, and the remaining kids were happy again.
